prior_works.title: Deep Unsupervised Learning using Nonequilibrium Thermodynamics
prior_works.authors: Jascha Sohl-Dickstein, Eric A. Weiss, Niru Maheswaranathan, Surya Ganguli
prior_works.role: Foundational diffusion framework (forward noising and reverse-time generative process) underpinning modern diffusion models.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper extends the original forward–reverse diffusion paradigm to a hybrid jump–diffusion that additionally corrupts and reconstructs dimensionality, directly generalizing Sohl-Dickstein et al.’s core construction.

prior_works.title: Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models
prior_works.authors: Jonathan Ho, Ajay Jain, Pieter Abbeel
prior_works.role: Practical discretized training and inference recipe for diffusion models.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Their discretized reverse-process parameterization and denoising objective inform the training of the reverse jump–diffusion dynamics, with this work augmenting DDPM to include dimension-creating jumps.

prior_works.title: Score-Based Generative Modeling through Stochastic Differential Equations
prior_works.authors: Yang Song, Jascha Sohl-Dickstein, Diederik P. Kingma, Abhishek Kumar, Stefano Ermon, Ben Poole
prior_works.role: Continuous-time SDE view and reverse-time SDE derivation for diffusion models.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The authors’ reverse-time SDE framework is generalized here to a reverse-time jump–diffusion that couples continuous state diffusion with discrete, trans-dimensional jump intensities.

prior_works.title: Structured Denoising Diffusion Models in Discrete State Spaces
prior_works.authors: Jacob Austin, Daniel D. Johnson, Jonathan Ho, Daniel Tarlow, Rianne van den Berg
prior_works.role: Diffusion modeling for discrete variables via Markov jump processes.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work’s treatment of discrete forward noising and learned reverse transitions motivates modeling the dimension variable as a jump process and learning its reverse dynamics jointly with continuous states.

prior_works.title: Reversible Jump Markov Chain Monte Carlo Computation and Bayesian Model Determination
prior_works.role: Seminal trans-dimensional inference with dimension-changing moves and matching constraints.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The proposed jump–diffusion inherits the core idea of principled, measure-consistent jumps between spaces of different dimensionality pioneered by reversible jump MCMC.

prior_works.title: On Bayesian Analysis of Mixtures with an Unknown Number of Components
prior_works.role: Birth–death style trans-dimensional moves in a concrete modeling setting.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Their use of birth/death transitions for creating and removing components directly inspires the paper’s dimension-destroying forward process and dimension-creating reverse process.

prior_works.title: Variational Diffusion Models
prior_works.authors: Diederik P. Kingma, Tim Salimans, Ben Poole, Jonathan Ho
prior_works.role: Variational (ELBO) view of diffusion model training.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The novel ELBO for learning the reverse jump–diffusion extends the VDM variational derivation to hybrid continuous–discrete, trans-dimensional paths.

synthesis_narrative:
The core contribution—learning a generative process that jointly models states and their dimensionality via a reverse-time jump–diffusion—sits at the intersection of diffusion modeling, discrete-state jump processes, and trans-dimensional inference. Foundational diffusion works (Sohl-Dickstein et al.; Ho et al.) provide the basic forward noising and reverse-time denoising framework and its practical discretization, while the score-based SDE view (Song et al.) elevates this to continuous time with a principled reverse-time SDE. Campbell et al. generalize that reverse-time construction to include stochastic jumps that change dimensionality, coupling continuous diffusion in state space with discrete jump intensities over dimension.

Handling a discrete component within a diffusion framework is directly informed by discrete diffusion advances (Austin et al.), which show how to model and learn reverse dynamics for jump-like corruption processes; here, that insight is applied specifically to the dimension variable and tightly coupled with continuous dynamics. The design of dimension-changing moves is rooted in the trans-dimensional MCMC literature: Reversible Jump MCMC (Green) establishes mathematically consistent transitions between spaces of differing dimension, and its birth–death instantiations (Richardson & Green) motivate the paper’s dimension-destroying forward process and dimension-creating reverse process. Finally, the training objective draws on the variational perspective of diffusion models (Kingma et al., VDM), which the authors extend to derive an ELBO appropriate for hybrid jump–diffusion paths. Together, these strands directly enable the paper’s principled, jointly learned sampler that generates both dimensionality and state.
